explanation: JavaScript has three ways to declare variables: var (old, avoid), let (block-scoped, can reassign), and const (block-scoped, cannot reassign). JavaScript is dynamically typed. Common types include Number, String, Boolean, Object, Array, null, and undefined.
syntax_notes: Use const by default, let when you need to reassign, avoid var. JavaScript has only one Number type (no separate int/float). Use typeof to check types. Template literals use backticks ` and ${} for interpolation.
common_mistakes: ["Using var instead of let/const", "Trying to reassign const variables", "Expecting const to make objects immutable", "Confusing null and undefined"]

explanation: JavaScript supports arithmetic (+, -, *, /, %, **), comparison (==, ===, !=, !==, <, >, <=, >=), and logical operators (&&, ||, !). Use === for strict equality (checks type and value).
syntax_notes: Use === and !== (strict equality) instead of == and !=. Logical operators: && (and), || (or), ! (not). Use ++ and -- for increment/decrement. Division always returns floating point.
common_mistakes: ["Using == instead of ===", "Confusing = (assignment) with === (comparison)", "Not understanding type coercion", "Expecting integer division with /"]

explanation: Strings in JavaScript can use single quotes, double quotes, or backticks (template literals). Strings are immutable. JavaScript provides many built-in string methods for manipulation.
syntax_notes: Use template literals `${}` for string interpolation. .length is a property (no parentheses). Strings are immutable. Methods return new strings. Use === for string comparison.
common_mistakes: ["Trying to modify strings directly (they're immutable)", "Using .length() with parentheses", "Confusing substring() and slice()", "Not using template literals"]

explanation: In JavaScript, console.log() outputs to the browser console or terminal. For user input in the browser, use prompt(). In Node.js, use readline or process.stdin. In web pages, use HTML forms and event listeners.
syntax_notes: console.log() works everywhere (browser console, Node.js terminal). prompt(), alert(), confirm() only work in browsers. For web apps, use HTML forms and DOM manipulation. For Node.js, use readline or process.stdin.
common_mistakes: ["Using prompt() in Node.js (doesn't exist)", "Forgetting to convert prompt() result from string", "Not sanitizing user input", "Using alert() excessively (annoying UX)"]

explanation: JavaScript supports // for single-line comments and /* */ for multi-line comments. Use JSDoc comments (/** */) for function documentation. Good comments explain WHY, not WHAT.
syntax_notes: Use // for single-line comments. Use /* */ for multi-line comments. Use /** */ (JSDoc) for function documentation. Comments are ignored by JavaScript engine. Common tags: TODO, FIXME, NOTE, HACK.
common_mistakes: ["Over-commenting obvious code", "Writing comments that contradict the code", "Not updating comments when code changes", "Using comments instead of clear variable names"]
